Examples

Multiply the following square matrices:

  1. \[ A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \qquad \mbox{and} \qquad B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \]
  2. \[ C= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 4 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \qquad \mbox{and} \qquad D= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

Solutions

  1. Recall that we multiply matrices by considering each combination of rows of the first matrix and columns of the second matrix and calculating their dot product. So here we have \[ AB = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} (1 \times 1) + (2 \times 1) & (1 \times 1) + (2 \times -1) \\ (3 \times 1) + (4 \times 1) & (3 \times 1) + (4 \times -1) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ 7 & -1 \end{bmatrix}. \]
  2. We proceed in the same way as in part a. but now we will have three elements in each sum rather than two. We have: \[ CD = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 4 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} (1 \times 1) + (2 \times 0) + (4 \times 0) & (1\times 0) + (2 \times 1) + (4 \times 0) & (1 \times 0) + (2 \times 0) + (4 \times 1) \\ (3 \times 1) + (4 \times 0) + (1 \times 0) & (3\times 0) + (4 \times 1) + (1 \times 0) & (3 \times 0) + (4 \times 0) + (1 \times 1) \\ (1 \times 1) + (0 \times 0) + (1 \times 0) & (1\times 0) + (0 \times 1) + (1 \times 0) & (1 \times 0) + (0 \times 0) + (1 \times 1) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 4 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}. \]

Notice that in part b. when we multiplied by the matrix \(D\) we ended up with the matrix \(C\) as the result of the multiplication. The matrix \[ D = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \] is the only matrix where this property holds. We call the matrix \(D\) the identity matrix Multiplying a square matrix by the identity matrix is like multiplying a number by \(1\). In general the \(n \times n\) identity matrix is the square matrix with ones on the main (top-left to bottom-right) diagonal and zeroes everywhere else. It is denoted by \(I_n\) and has the property that \[ I_n A = A I_n = A, \] for any \(n \times n\) square matrix \(A\).
